importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's update indicates the most current information on the Blue Jays' World Series advancement, reflecting the culmination of the ALCS and the start of a historic postseason run.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The ALCS took place from mid-October 2025, culminating in Game 7 on October 21, marking the transition from playoff competition to the World Series.

keyTakeAways: George Springer's three-run home run in the seventh inning turned a losing game into a victory, securing the Blue Jays' ALCS win and their first World Series berth since 1993.
The Blue Jays' victory over the Seattle Mariners in Game 7 marks their first appearance in the World Series since 1993, a significant milestone in Canadian baseball history.
Vladimir Guerrero Jr. was named ALCS MVP after a .385 batting average and three home runs in the series, highlighting key individual performance in the playoff run.
The game was marred by controversy involving a disputed play where Julio Rodriguez reached base after a ricochet off Naylor’s helmet, leading to a call that ultimately ended the inning.
Despite Springer being injured in Game 5 and showing discomfort in Games 6 and 7, he returned to pitch in Game 7, demonstrating resilience and dedication to the team and fans.
The Blue Jays will face the Los Angeles Dodgers in the World Series, making it a high-stakes matchup between the AL’s top team and the defending champion.
The Seattle Mariners remain the only MLB franchise never to have reached a World Series, adding narrative significance to their elimination in the ALCS.

namedEntities.name: George Springer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professional baseball player, designated hitter for the Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Springer's dramatic three-run home run in Game 7 was the pivotal moment that won the ALCS and propelled the Blue Jays to the World Series, making him the central figure in the story.

namedEntities.name: Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professional baseball team based in Toronto, Canada
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays' victory in Game 7 of the ALCS marks their first World Series appearance since 1993, representing a major achievement in Canadian sports history.

namedEntities.name: Seattle Mariners
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professional baseball team based in Seattle, Washington
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Mariners were the opposing team in the ALCS, and their elimination in Game 7 ended their playoff journey, highlighting a historic milestone for the franchise.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Dodgers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professional baseball team based in Los Angeles, California
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dodgers are the defending champions and the opponent in the World Series, making the matchup a significant event in MLB postseason history.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Guerrero Jr.
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professional baseball player, key hitter for the Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Guerrero Jr. was named ALCS MVP due to his outstanding performance, including three home runs and a .385 batting average, underscoring the team’s offensive strength.

namedEntities.name: Julio Rodriguez
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professional baseball player, outfielder for the Seattle Mariners
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rodriguez had a strong series performance with multiple home runs and a lead-off double, setting the tone early in the game and contributing to the Mariners’ offense.

namedEntities.name: Cal Raleigh
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professional baseball player, outfielder for the Seattle Mariners
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Raleigh hit a fifth long ball in the playoffs and was a key offensive contributor for the Mariners, showing his value as a high-scoring player.

namedEntities.name: Eduardo Bazardo
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pitcher for the Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bazardo entered the game in the seventh inning and faced George Springer, who hit a decisive three-run homer off his pitch.

namedEntities.name: Shane Bieber
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bieber pitched in the series and allowed a solo home run by Rodriguez in the third inning, contributing to the Mariners' scoring.

namedEntities.name: Chris Bassitt
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pitcher for the Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bassitt pitched a scoreless eighth inning, helping preserve the Blue Jays’ lead during the game.

namedEntities.name: Jeff Hoffman
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pitcher for the Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hoffman closed the game in the ninth inning with a perfect inning, securing the win and ending the game with a three-out strikeout.

namedEntities.name: Ernie Clement
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Third baseman for the Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Clement made a throw during a controversial play that ricocheted off Naylor’s helmet, resulting in a disputed call and a pivotal moment in the game.

namedEntities.name: Josh Naylor
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Naylor hit a single to drive in Rodriguez in the first inning and was involved in the controversial play where his helmet caused a ricochet that led to a disputed call.

namedEntities.name: Jorge Polanco
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Polanco hit a groundball that led to the controversial play, and was called out after the ricochet due to a ruling on obstruction.

namedEntities.name: Daulton Varsho
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Player for the Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Varsho tied the game 1-1 with a groundball single in the bottom of the first inning, marking the Blue Jays’ first offensive response.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Toronto Blue Jays advanced to their first World Series since 1993 by defeating the Seattle Mariners 4-3 in Game 7 of the American League Championship Series, fueled by a pivotal three-run home run from George Springer in the seventh inning. The game featured a controversial play involving a ricochet off Josh Naylor’s helmet that led to a disputed call, but the Blue Jays maintained momentum, with Vladimir Guerrero Jr. earning ALCS MVP honors for his .385 average and three home runs. Despite Springer's injury in earlier games, he returned to deliver the decisive hit, and the Blue Jays secured a win with a scoreless eighth and ninth inning from Chris Bassitt and Jeff Hoffman. The Blue Jays will face the defending champion Los Angeles Dodgers in the World Series, while the Mariners remain the only MLB franchise never to reach a World Series.
title: George Springer’s epic home run helps send the Toronto Blue Jays to the World Series with ALCS Game 7 win over Seattle
